results.headline: A Thug Talks and Talks, and Scribbles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Sicario Room 164

results.summary_short: In “El Sicario, Room 164,”’ a reformed hit man for the Mexican drug cartel regales us with 20 years’ worth of kidnapping, torture and cold-blooded murder.

results.headline: Poof to Life as You Knew It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Darkest Hour

results.summary_short: In “The Darkest Hour,” four young adults partying in Moscow fight for their lives when aliens invade and glowing fireballs transform most of humanity into cremains.

results.headline: A Hero With a Snout and a Tender Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Porco Rosso

results.summary_short: Hayao Miyazaki’s animated 1992 adventure “Porco Rosso” introduces an unlikely hero: a seaplane pilot with the head of a pig and the heart of Rhett Butler.

results.headline: A Cat Knows a Thing or Two About Scoops

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Minoes

results.summary_short: “Miss Minoes,” a Dutch film by Vincent Bal, is a pleasantly quirky, family-friendly fable with lots of meowing.

results.headline: Innocence Is Trampled, but a Bond Endures

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Horse

results.summary_short: “War Horse,” set in World War I and directed by Steven Spielberg, pays tribute to a tradition of honest, emotionally direct storytelling.

results.headline: A Modern-Day Ark, With Children, Animals and Even Romance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Bought a Zoo

results.summary_short: In Cameron Crowe’s “We Bought a Zoo” Matt Damon plays a single father who is raising his two children and trying to revive a zoo.

results.headline: 3-D Tribute to Artistic Impulse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pina

results.summary_short: Wim Wenders’s documentary “Pina” is a tribute to the German dancer and choreographer Pina Bausch, who died in 2009.

results.headline: A Youngster With a Key, a Word and a Quest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close

results.summary_short: “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” a film with Sept. 11 as a backdrop, stars Tom Hanks and the young newcomer Thomas Horn, and is based on the novel by Jonathan Safran Foer.

results.headline: Bollywood Baddie Is Ready to Take On Europe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don: The King Is Back

results.summary_short: In “Don 2,” a sequel to a 2006 Indian hit, the young criminal kingpin Don (Shah Rukh Khan) is back, and “now my target is Europe!”

results.headline: In a Fractured Society, Ethnic War Kindles Both Hatred and Desire
results.display_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Land of Blood and Honey

results.summary_short: Bosnia in 1992, as the ethnic war begins, is the backdrop for “In the Land of Blood and Honey,” Angelina Jolie’s directorial debut.

results.headline: Intrepid Boy on the Trail of Mysteries

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Adventures of Tintin

results.summary_short: Steven Spielberg’s “Adventures of Tintin” brings to computerized life a boy of pluck, ingenuity and derring-do.

results.headline: A Shady American in the Nanjing Massacre

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Flowers of War

results.summary_short: In “The Flowers of War,” the director Zhang Yimou revisits the 1937 Nanjing massacre in a story narrated by a convent student taking refuge in a church.

results.headline: Finding a Safe Harbor in Male Identity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Albert Nobbs

results.summary_short: Glenn Close’s portrayal of Albert Nobbs, a woman disguised as a man in late-19th-century Ireland, is both charming and sad.

results.headline: Tattooed Heroine Metes Out Slick, Punitive Violence
results.display_title: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

results.summary_short: David Fincher’s adaptation of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” starring Rooney Mara and Daniel Craig, holds onto the vivid and passionate essence of the book.

results.headline: Holmes and Watson, but Is There Mystery?
results.display_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows

results.summary_short: “Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows” confects a smoky, overcast Victorian world, infuses it with an air of jocular, hairy laddishness and stages a lot of fights.

results.headline: Blood Sport in a High-Rise

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carnage

results.summary_short: In “Carnage,” Roman Polanski’s spry adaptation of Yasmina Reza’s play, two couples show that beneath the surface of civilized behavior lurks animal impulses.

results.headline: Falling Off Skyscrapers Sometimes Hurts a Bit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mission: Impossible Ghost Protocol

results.summary_short: In “Mission: Impossible — Ghost Protocol,” directed by Brad Bird, Tom Cruise does his stunts with an unnerving intensity.

results.headline: The King of the B-Movie and His A-List Following
results.display_title: Corman's World: Exploits of a Hollywood Rebel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Corman's World: Exploits of a Hollywood Rebel

results.summary_short: Alex Stapleton’s “Corman’s World: Exploits of a Hollywood Rebel” is a fond look at the influence of Roger Corman, a prolific director and prodigious nurturer of talent.

results.headline: Addicts, a 6-Year-Old and an East Texas Meth Lab

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cook County

results.summary_short: In “Cook County,” a family faces the perils of drug addiction and child care.

results.headline: Shipwrecked, and Landing New Personalities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked

results.summary_short: The Chipmunks go on a cruise that ends badly (with the Chipettes along for the ride).
